topic.title: Advanced Error Reporting

body.p: Switchtec is fully compatible with the PCIe Base Specification 4.0 in transparent mode operation. There are some special error handling cases in Non-Transparent switch operation which will be described separately .

AER is supported as a combination of hardware and firmware. The hardware is responsible for the error detection. The firmware is responsible for the error reporting and logging. The errors described below are associated with specific actions to log and report the error. The term ‘uncorrectable error processing’ and ‘correctable error processing’ refers to the processing described in PCI Express Base 4.0 Specification.
For PSX customers, there are a set of APIs can be used to override the default error handling procedure for customization purposes.
The following uncorrectable errors are handled as Internal Errors (IER). Details of IER are found here:

section.title: Error Detected By AER

fig.title: Advanced Error Detected By AER Hardware

section.p: The AER Detection block snoops the busses from the PL/DL block similar to the IPR Error Detection block and makes the following error detection:

ul.li: CA in completion (Completion Aborted, Not PCIe spec defined)
UR in completion (Unsupported Request, Not PCIe spec defined)

section.p: When AER is triggered, the first TLP header is logged (TLP Header Prefix).
Some AER-defined errors are detected by the IPR Error Detection block and in addition priority encoding is used in detection of Malformed TLPs.

The AER detection block receives two sets of following signals from the IPR block on the same cycle as it receives the incoming TDM TLPs. The TDM cycle between the IPR Error Detection block and the AER Detection block are synchronized.

row.entry: Payload size not matching Length field
TLP with TD bit set, but has no ECRC
Completion with Less/more data than length
IO Req Header field checks (Length, TC, Attr, Last BE)
Config Req Header field checks (Length, TC, Attr, Last BE)
Mem TLP/Transactions with TC other than TC0.
MSG with routing 000 at Upstream port
MSG with routing 011 at Downstream port
Receiving MSG with routing "101" not PME_To_Ack.
Receiving TLP with Prefix - error because we do not support TLP Prefix
Payload size not matching Length field
TLP with TD bit set, but has no ECRC
Completion with Less/more data then length (special case of Length check by NWL)
IO Req Header field checks (Length, TC, Attr, Last BE)
Config Req Header field checks (Length, TC, Attr, Last BE)
Mem TLP/Transactions with TC other than TC0.
MSG with routing 000 at Upstream port
MSG with routing 011 at Downstream port
Receiving MSG with routing "101" not PME_To_Ack.
Receiving TLP with Prefix - error because we do not support TLP Prefix

section.p: Multiple error detection for the same ingress TLP may occur and since two TLPs can be received on the same clock cycle, different errors can be detected for both TLPs on the same clock cycle. The AER Detection block categorizes all of the detected errors into Uncorrectable Errors (UE) and Correctable Errors (CE) as defined in the UE Status Register and CE Status Register of the PCIe Spec r3.1.

section.title: Error Detected By RST
section.p: These unroutable TLP errors and blocked TLP errors are detected by the RST. The error TLP is either forwarded to PPU to handle or forwarded to destination port's EPR to drop and log.

section.title: AER Logging
section.p: The AER Hardware Logging Memory is used as a header log queue to avoid log missing when Firmware has no chance to dump it before the following AERs occur.

The depth of the AER Hardware Logging Memory is 32 for every PCIe stack. For the x16 case, only Port 0 AER Log FIFO controller is active and is allocated with all 32 entries. For the 2 x8 case, only Port 0 and Port 4 AER Log FIFO controllers are active and each is allocated with 16 entries. Each AER Log FIFO controller outputs a full signal along with the FIFO occupancy level. Firmware uses this value to get the number of the error buffered. When an error is detected by AER hardware to certain port and the allocated buffer has been filled, an AER error Header Log Overflow will be sent to the AER Detection block.
The following uncorrectable errors are logged at AER hardware:

ul.li: Completer Abort Status in Completion TLP (Not used)
Unsupported Request Error Status in Completion TLP (Not used)

section.p: The following information is written into the AER Log entry:

ul.li: AER Trigger Info: Errors that triggered the particular header log entry

section.title: AER EPR Hardware
section.p: The depth of the EPR Hardware Logging Memory is 1 for each port per blocking type. If back-to-back error happens, the firmware can only report the first logged error.
The following uncorrectable errors are logged at EPR hardware:

ul.li: TLP Blocked by Bus Master Enable, Memory Space Enable or IO Space Enable
First TLP Blocked by link down

section.p: The following information is written into the EPR Log entry:

ul.li: EPR Trigger Info: Errors that triggered the particular header log entry

section.p: Since errors can be detected in multiple stages in the application layer, the firmware should maintain all the errors and logged TLP header in the RAM. The firmware allocates 5 header log spaces for each function. When the hardware AER and EPR notifies the firmware about the error, the firmware would dump the error log information and save it into the RAM . Firmware can read the AER Memory one entry at a time via register access. Read entry is immediately de-queued from the AER Memory. A register status field indicates the number of occupied entries in the AER Memory.

To access the AER Logged entries for each port, the PORT_ID bit field in the AER Log Read Control Register needs to be set to the corresponding port number and the TIP bit field set to ‘1’. For example, to read from port 4 of the Switch Port, the PORT_ID should be set to 4 and TIP set to ‘1’. Upon detecting the rising edge of the TIP bit, a read is sent to the AER Log FIFO Controller of port 4. The read data is then written to AER Log Header Registers 1 to 6 and the TIP bit is cleared to ‘0’.
In scenarios where a FIFO reset is required, all AER Log entries of a particular port can be cleared by setting the associated FIFO Flush bit field in the UE Control Register.

Two test registers are introduced to test the AER logging logic; AER UE Test Register and AER CE Test Register. Values from these registers are sent to the AER Detection block and merged with the normal detection logic before sending to the AER Caching block. When a bit field in a Test Register is set to ‘1’, the associated AER error belonging to the active TDM port will be sent to the AER Caching block. Writing a ‘0’ to the Test Register clears the associated AER detection.

section.title: AER Test
section.p: Two test registers are introduced to test the AER logging logic; AER UE Test Register and AER CE Test Register. Values from these registers are sent to the AER Detection block and merged with the normal detection logic before sending to the AER Caching block. When a bit field in a Test Register is set to ‘1’, the associated AER error belonging to the active TDM port will be sent to the AER Caching block. Writing a ‘0’ to the Test Register clears the associated AER detection.
